Generating pseudo absences from raster layers for distribution modeling.

Source: R/sdmdataprep.R
envextract.Rd

Generating pseudo absences from raster layers for distribution modeling.

Usage

envextract(
  occurences,
  raster,
  lat = NULL,
  lon = NULL,
  geom = FALSE,
  binary = FALSE,
  labels = NULL,
  prop = 0.8,
  set.seed = 1124,
  positive = NULL,
  missingness = 0.1,
  exclude = NULL,
  vifcutoff = 0.9,
  verbose = FALSE
)

Arguments

occurences

Species occurrences data with coordinates or geometry to enable generate pseudo absences and extract environmental data from the points.

raster

A raster layer with species environmental data to be used during modelling. Different sources, include WORLDCLIM

lat, lon

If the species occurrences don't have the geometry column or not spatial vector file, the latitude and longitude must be provided for data extraction form the raster layers.

geom

Is used in data extraction when the species occurrences geometry column instead of latitude and longitude.

binary

Either FALSE if the species dataset do not have label column for presence absence. Therefore, the FALSE is used when the parameter label is NULL. If only species presences and absences are indicated, the user should select TRUE option.

labels

If the dataset has presence absence column, it should be indicated here to be used for extracting the labels. Character labels for example allowed, for example P for presences and A for absences recommended.

prop

The proportion of pseudo absences to presences. Default of 1 is used. Therefore equal number of pseudo absences are generated commensurate to the species.

set.seed

to ensure reproduciblity the seed is set. Same psudoabsences will be produced during each run.

positive

if TRUE is used, the user should indicate the positive label. For example, P for presence label. This is important in fitting the models and computing the evaluation metrics.

missingness

Allowed missing values in a column to allow a user decide whether to remove the individual columns or rows from the data sets. Default 0.1. Therefore, if if a column has more than 10% missing values, then it will be removed from the dataset rather than the rows.

exclude

Remove non numeric variables from the data.

vifcutoff

Used in assessing multicolinearity in environmental predictors using correlation from vifcor function from usdm package Naimi et al., 2014.

verbose

Either TRUE to return messages or FALSE for no implementation messages. Default FALSE

Value

Labeled presence absence data.

Details

In this package, this fucntion was developed to aid in preparing the data for developing species distribution models in sdmfit. If only species occurrences or absences are available, the function generates pseudo absences required in species distribution modeling. If the data is binary with both presences and absences, the user has to set which label denotes the presence of species using the positive parameter. The user should indicate the column where the labels are found. To account for multicolinearity among the environmental predictors, we used the vifcor function from usdm to drop highly correlated environmental predictors. Therefore, user can adjust the vifcutoff to range from 0 to 1.

References

  1. Naimi, B., Hamm, N. A., Groen, T. A., Skidmore, A. K., & Toxopeus, A. G. (2014). Where is positional uncertainty a problem for species distribution modelling?. Ecography, 37(2), 191-203.

Examples


if (FALSE) {

data(efidata)

#select species with enough records
#1. Presence data: the final dataset has both presence and pseudo absences
 dfprep <- envextract(occurences = efidata, raster = worldclim,
                        lat = "decimalLatitude", lon = "decimalLongitude",
                        binary = FALSE, prop = 0.8)

#2. Prensence absence

efidata$pa <- rep(c("A", "P"), c(nrow(efidata)/2, nrow(efidata)/2))

dfprep <- envextract(occurences = efidata, raster = worldclim, lat = "decimalLatitude",
                    lon = "decimalLongitude", binary = TRUE,
                    positive = "P", labels = "pa", vifcutoff = 0.9)

 #3. With sf geometry column

 efisfdata <- sf::st_as_sf(efidata, coords = c("decimalLongitude",
 "decimalLatitude"), crs= sf::st_crs(4326))

 dfprep_geom <- envextract(occurences = efisfdata, raster = worldclim,
                          geom = 'geometry', binary = TRUE,
                          positive = "P", labels = "pa", vifcutoff = 0.9)
}
